CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Art. 8;Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Angelika Nußberger;Dean Spielmann;Elisabet Fura;Ganna Yudkivska;Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE . His daughter and son were born in DATE and DATE respectively .

CARDINAL . The applicant and the mother of the above - mentioned girl and boy ( “ the mother ” ) , who were the only children she and the applicant had together , separated in DATE . At that time the mother moved out of the house in which they had lived together . The children stayed with the applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a claim for custody and , as alternative , a request for contact arrangements . He also requested that an interim decision be issued pending final determination of the case .
CARDINAL . On DATE the mother took the children to live with her .

CARDINAL . Further to a request by the court , ORG submitted a report on DATE . On DATE the court held a hearing and issued an interim decision granting provisional custody to the applicant . It would appear that this decision was not enforced at that time and the children did therefore not move to the applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE , at the second hearing in the case , the mother objected to the interim decision and requested the resumption of the previous state of affairs . Since it was established that the mother had not received the court decision , the court revoked it .

CARDINAL . On DATE the parties entered into an agreement before ORG concerning the applicant ’s contact with the children . According to the agreement , the children were to spend DATE TIME and every other DATE with the applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the mother lodged a counterclaim for custody and a request for an interim decision granting her provisional custody . On DATE , as well as on DATE , the applicant also requested the court to issue an interim decision .
CARDINAL . Further to the court ’s request , ORG submitted an additional report on DATE .

CARDINAL . The mother prevented the applicant from having contact with the children during DATE of DATE , by taking the children to her relatives . In this connection , the applicant lodged a criminal complaint of abduction of the children , which was dismissed as of minor importance on DATE .
CARDINAL . A hearing was held on DATE . Subsequently , on DATE , the court requested a report from an expert psychologist .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant made written submissions , in which he mentioned that since the last hearing the mother had prevented him from having contact with the children on DATE , DATE , and DATE of DATE , but nevertheless requested the court to suspend the proceedings , as he and the mother might reach a settlement . On DATE , however , he complained that the mother had not allowed him to see the children during the GPE and DATE and the proceedings therefore continued .

CARDINAL . On DATE the expert submitted his report , which was forwarded to the parties for comments . On DATE the applicant informed the court that he had spent the holiday with the children CARDINAL and DATE and requested that that an interim decision be issued .
CARDINAL . On DATE the court held a brief hearing , which was adjourned for further evidence to be obtained by the court .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , on DATE , the court ordered the applicant to pay the expert ’s fees . He appealed against this decision and on CARDINAL DATE requested the court to send the file to the higher court for consideration of his appeal . At the same time he again requested that an interim decision be issued .
CARDINAL . On DATE the case was taken up by a new judge specialising in family matters . The applicant again urged the judge to issue an interim decision .

CARDINAL . NORP The court scheduled a hearing for DATE , which was adjourned at the request of the applicant , stating that the parties would again try to reach a settlement . However , on DATE the applicant again requested the court to issue an interim decision .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court held a hearing at which the applicant complained about having only very poor contact with his children , which was brought to the attention of the welfare office . The applicant further explained that after the agreement had been signed on DATE he had had contact with the children during the subsequent DATE . After that , however , the contact was obstructed , partly also because the agreement did not include arrangements for contact during holidays . The applicant then confirmed that the children had spent DATE of DATE with him , but that he had been prevented from spending all the CARDINAL holidays in DATE with them . The next hearing was scheduled for DATE . However , after the applicant informed the court that he was again unable to have contact with the children , the court changed the date of the next hearing to CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . At the hearing of DATE the applicant stated that he had not had contact with his children on a regular basis since DATE . The court , however , noted that the applicant had had contact with the children on DATE , and of its own motion issued an interim decision granting provisional custody to the mother and setting out new provisional contact arrangements allowing the applicant to have contact TIME per week . The applicant objected .
CARDINAL . On DATE the judge held a meeting with the children .

CARDINAL . At the hearing of DATE the judge attempted to reach a friendly settlement , but to no avail . On DATE the court upheld in part the applicant ’s objection to the interim decision of DATE and issued a new interim decision setting out provisional contact arrangements , so that the applicant was allowed to spend with the children every DATE TIME , DATE , and part of DATE . The applicant was to pick up the children from school and take them to the mother ’s home after the visit . The decision also included a provision that failure to comply with the contact arrangements would result in a fine of CARDINAL NORP tolars ( SIT ) .
CARDINAL . The parties appealed . Consequently , the court sent the file to the higher court and requested priority treatment .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed appeals against the interim decision of DATE and an appeal by the applicant against the decision of DATE concerning expert fees . The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law which was declared inadmissible by ORG . The applicant appealed against this decision .

CARDINAL . After DATE the mother started to prevent the applicant ’s contact with the children . On DATE she also lodged a criminal complaint against the applicant for neglect and maltreatment of a minor . The criminal complaints related to an incident when the applicant allowed his daughter to read a book by PERSON , CARDINAL Strokes of the Brush Before Bed . The public prosecutor requested the court to undertake certain investigating measures , such as questioning the applicant . The criminal complaint was subsequently dismissed as unfounded on DATE . The public prosecutor noted that the daughter , who read only a few pages , was not pushed by the applicant to read the book , which was intended for teenagers .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant attempted to pick up the children from their mother ’s home to take them for the scheduled holiday . As the mother refused to comply with the interim decision of DATE , the court issued a decision on DATE , stating that the applicant ’s contact with the children during the holiday should be secured by removing the children from whoever they were with on DATE . Further to the delivery of this decision the enforcement was attempted . It failed , however , as the mother informed the welfare officer that she had lodged a criminal complaint against the applicant ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above ) . Consequently , the welfare officer advised the enforcing officer to discontinue the enforcement ( see paragraph DATE , section CARDINALf , above ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE the court made inquiries about the allegations made against the applicant to the relevant prosecutor ’s office , the police and the welfare office .
CARDINAL . Due to the pending appeal ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) the case was sent to the higher court on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the mother objected to the enforcement decision of CARDINAL DATE . Her objection was dismissed on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the mother requested that the provisional contact arrangements be modified so that the applicant could only have very limited contact with the children , under the supervision of the welfare office .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the applicant ’s appeal against the first - instance decision dismissing his appeal on points of law .

CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL , DATE and DATE the applicant lodged requests for fines to be imposed for non - compliance by the mother with the contact arrangements of DATE , amounting to SIT CARDINAL in total . He also urged the court to issue a new interim decision .

CARDINAL . A hearing was held on DATE . According to the transcript of the hearing , the applicant told the judge that he had not had any contact with the children since DATE . The mother said that the applicant had , during DATE to DATE , allowed the daughter to read an inappropriate book , which the applicant denied , saying that the daughter had taken the book as it had an interesting cover page but had not read it ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . The applicant was then asked by the judge if he would agree with the mother ’s proposal to have contact supervised by ORG . He agreed at first . However , his representative then stated that the applicant believed that it would be unpleasant for the children to have contact with him under supervision . The judge then appointed an expert in psychology to prepare a new report and stated that she would not issue any decisions imposing fines , due to new circumstances which required the preparation of a new expert report . She further stated that the imposition of monetary fines would be a less severe sanction than removal of the children by force , which had already failed , and would not be reasonable in view of the fact that the applicant was not paying the full amount of maintenance .
CARDINAL . On DATE a new expert psychologist was appointed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a constitutional appeal , complaining that the judge had arbitrarily refused to decide on his enforcement requests , depriving him of the opportunity to appeal . On DATE ORG , relying on section CARDINAL of LAW , dismissed the appeal , finding that it did not concern a specific decision of a State body , and noted that “ there was no right to lodge a constitutional appeal directly against the act or omission of the ORG authorities . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested that the provisional contact arrangements be modified and on DATE he lodged a new request for an interim decision .
CARDINAL . NORP On DATE the judge held a meeting with the expert and then decided also to appoint a psychiatrist to examine the parents .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested the judge to step down . The request was rejected by the president of the court on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the psychiatrist ’s report was sent to the parties for comments .

CARDINAL . In the period DATE and DATE the applicant lodged further CARDINAL requests for fines , in a total sum of SIT CARDINAL , to be imposed on the mother for her non - compliance with the contact arrangements in the period between DATE and DATE .

CARDINAL . At the hearing of DATE the court questioned the experts . The court noted that according to the expert reports both parents were suitable for parenting . It also issued a new interim decision modifying the provisional contact arrangements so that the applicant had a right to spend every other DATE with the children ( from DATE ) and every DATE TIME and a part of upcoming holiday . The court prohibited the mother from picking up the children from school on DATE that they were supposed to be with the applicant . The representative of the applicant confirmed at the subsequent hearings that these contact arrangements were being complied with by the mother .
CARDINAL . The mother was ordered to pay the expert ’s fees . She appealed , unsuccessfully .

CARDINAL . At the hearing of DATE a conditional settlement was prepared at the proposal of the applicant . At the next hearing , on CARDINAL DATE , the applicant ’s representative confirmed that the applicant and the children had had regular contact , in line with the latest contact arrangements . The parties agreed that they would terminate the pending criminal proceedings they had instituted against each other .
CARDINAL . On DATE the court held a hearing at which the applicant again confirmed that contact arrangements were being complied with .
CARDINAL . On DATE the expert report was supplemented at the request of the court .

DATE . On DATE the parties reached an agreement on custody and contact rights . The agreement provided that the mother had sole custody of the children and set out contact arrangements for the applicant and the children who were to spend every DATE TIME , every other DATE ( from DATE ) and CARDINAL the school holidays together .

CARDINAL . In the course of the proceedings the applicant , in addition to the criminal complaint mentioned above ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , lodged a number of further criminal complaints against the mother concerning criminal offences of , inter alia , child abduction and sexual violence against a minor . The mother also lodged CARDINAL criminal complaints against the applicant . CARDINAL of them concerned abduction , the other concerned alleged neglect and maltreatment of a minor ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . All criminal complaints were ultimately dismissed by the public prosecutor .

CARDINAL . As regards the relevant provisions of domestic family law see PERSON and PERSON , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL and GPE , § § DATE , DATE . In addition , the following legislation is relevant to the present case .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW ( PERSON , ORG no . CARDINAL with amendments ) provides , in so far as relevant , as follows :
“ Everyone has the right to have any decision regarding his rights , duties and any charges brought against him made without undue delay by an independent , impartial court constituted by law .
CARDINAL . LAW ( Zakon o pravdnem postopku , Official Gazette no . CARDINAL with amendments ) provided , in so far as relevant :
“ ( CARDINAL ) An appeal is allowed against any first - instance decision , unless a law provides otherwise .

“ ( CARDINAL ) NORP In marital disputes and disputes concerning relations between parents and children the courts shall of their own motion take all steps necessary to safeguard the rights and interests of the children ...

( CARDINAL ) In disputes concerning the custody and maintenance of children and in disputes concerning contacts between children and parents or other persons , the panel is not bound by the parties’ requests . Where so provided by the law , the panel may take decisions even when no request has been made .

( CARDINAL ) For the protection of the interests of the persons mentioned in the first paragraph , the panel may investigate matters not presented by the parties , and collect information necessary for a decision ... ”

“ ( CARDINAL ) During proceedings concerning marital disputes and disputes relating to relationships between parents and children , the court may , at the request of CARDINAL of the parties or of its own motion , issue interim decisions concerning child custody and maintenance as well as interim decisions withdrawing or restricting contact rights and determining contact arrangements .
CARDINAL . The Execution of Judgments and Insurance of Claims Act ( Zakon o izvršbi in zavarovanju , ORG no . DATE with amendments ) provided , as far as relevant :
“ ( CARDINAL ) An appeal is allowed against any first - instance decision , unless a law provides otherwise .
“ In enforcement proceedings provisions of LAW should apply , unless a law provides otherwise . ”

“ ( CARDINAL ) If a person under obligation ( dolžnik ) [ “ the defaulter ” ] is obliged to do something specified under the enforcement provision of a decision , and which can not be done by anyone else , the court shall issue a decision setting a deadline for the fulfilment of the obligation .
( CARDINAL ) In an enforcement decision , the court shall set out a fine for the eventuality that the defaulter does not fulfil the obligation within the time - limit set by the court . ....

( CARDINAL ) If the defaulter does not fulfil the obligation , the court shall order ex officio execution based on the decision imposing a fine . At the same time , the court shall issue a new decision setting a new deadline for the fulfilment of the obligation , and a new fine , higher than the CARDINAL previously imposed , in the event that the defaulter fails to comply again .
( CARDINAL ) When determining the fine the court should take into account the importance of the act that should be performed by the defaulter and other circumstance of the case . ”
( CARDINAL ) The court is not bound by the requested means of enforcement .
( CARDINAL ) When it is necessary for protection of the child ’s interests the court can change the means of enforcement provided for in the enforcement order . ”
“ ( CARDINAL ) A court ’s decision concerning the right to have contact with a child shall be enforced in accordance with first , second , third and fifth paragraph of section CARDINAL of this Act .

( CARDINAL ) NORP In exceptional and particularly justified cases , when this would be necessary for the protection of the child ’s interests and the enforcement mentioned in the preceding paragraph was unsuccessful , the court may allow the enforcement as prescribed in section CARDINALe of this LAW [ direct removal ] .
( CARDINAL ) Provisions of sections ORG , ORG and ORG [ which concern the enforcement of custody decisions ] should be used mutatis mutandis in these proceedings .

( CARDINAL ) NORP If , during the enforcement under the second paragraph , the enforcing officer observes that the child opposes the contact ... and finds that the enforcement by means of removing the child would not be in the child ’s interest , he or she can discontinue the procedure and inform the court about the reasons .

( CARDINAL ) If the court establishes that the child opposes the contact ... , and finds that the enforcement by means of removal of the child would not be in the child ’s interest ... it can , at the request of the enforcing officer ... or the person against whom the enforcement is carried out , suspend the enforcement for DATE at most .

( CARDINAL ) The court can suspend the enforcement at the request of the welfare office or the person against whom the enforcement is conducted also when the proceedings for a modification of contact arrangements are pending or if the enforcement would be against the child ’s interests . ”
“ ( CARDINAL ) The court shall issue an interim decision in order to protect a non - pecuniary claim , if the claimant shows that he the claim is likely to be established ... ”

( CARDINAL ) At the request of the debtor , the court should discontinue [ enforcement ] proceedings and invalidate the actions already taken if the circumstances on the basis of which the interim decision had been adopted have changed so that the interim decision is no longer needed . ”
CARDINAL . Finally , section CARDINAL of LAW ( Zakon o ustavnem sodišču , Official Gazette no . DATE with amendments ) , provides , as far as relevant :

“ ( CARDINAL ) Due to a violation of human rights or fundamental freedoms , a constitutional complaint may , under the conditions determined by this LAW , be lodged against individual acts by which state authorities , local authorities , or holders of public powers decided on the rights , obligations , or legal entitlements of individuals or legal entities .
